description:
Drosophila navojoa is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the genus Drosophila. It is native to Mexico, specifically the region around the town of Navojoa in the state of Sonora.

Drosophila navojoa is a small insect, typically measuring around 2-3 millimeters in length. It has the characteristic features of a fruit fly, including a pair of wings, large compound eyes, and a slender body.

Genetically, Drosophila navojoa is closely related to other Drosophila species, and it is often used as a model organism in genetic and developmental research due to its short life cycle, well-understood genetics, and ease of laboratory cultivation.

The species is known to feed on overripe or fermenting fruits, which serve as a source of food and breeding substrate for the flies. Drosophila navojoa plays a role in the decomposition and nutrient cycling of these plant materials in its native ecosystem.

Overall, Drosophila navojoa is a valuable subject for scientific research, contributing to our understanding of various biological processes and the ecology of fruit fly species in the region.
